Dialogue: I imagine so.

Dialogue: Except you.

Dialogue: Why don't you go away?

Dialogue: I'm sorry... I didn't mean it to sound uncaring...

Dialogue: Norman.

Dialogue: Nothing! You're putting me on the defensive.

Speaker: lila
Dialogue: Look, if you two are in this thing together, I don't care, it's none of my business... But I want to see Mary. I want her to tell me she's all right and it's none of my business. Then I'll go back to Phoenix and...

Speaker: sam
Dialogue: Bob? Run out and get yourself some lunch.

Speaker: summerfield
Dialogue: It's okay, Sam, I brought it with me.

Speaker: sam
Dialogue: Run out and eat it.

Speaker: sam
Dialogue: What thing?

Speaker: lila
Dialogue: Huh?

Speaker: sam
Dialogue: What thing could we be in together?

Speaker: sam
Dialogue: Is Mary... in trouble?

Speaker: lila
Dialogue: Yes.

Speaker: sam
Dialogue: Well why didn't she come to me... call me...?

Speaker: lila
Dialogue: Not that kind...  You men and your egos.

Speaker: sam
Dialogue: Never mind my ego. Let's talk about Mary.

Speaker: arbogast
Dialogue: Let's all talk about Mary.

Speaker: sam
Dialogue: Who are you, friend?

Speaker: arbogast
Dialogue: Milt Arbogast, Private Investigator.  Where is she, Miss Crane?

Speaker: lila
Dialogue: I don't know.

Speaker: arbogast
Dialogue: Wouldn't have been able to tail you if you did.

Speaker: sam
Dialogue: What's your interest?

Speaker: arbogast
Dialogue: Money.

Speaker: sam
Dialogue: Somebody better tell me what's going on and tell me fast! I can take so much and then...

Speaker: arbogast
Dialogue: Your girl friend stole forty thousand dollars.

Speaker: sam
Dialogue: Why?

Speaker: arbogast
Dialogue: Must've needed it.

Speaker: sam
Dialogue: What are you talking about?  What is this?

Speaker: lila
Dialogue: She was supposed to bank it, on Friday, for her boss. She didn't.

Speaker: arbogast
Dialogue: She is your girl friend, isn't she?

Speaker: lila
Dialogue: Sam, they don't want to prosecute, they just want the money back. It was all in cash...

Speaker: arbogast
Dialogue: Casharoonie!

Speaker: lila
Dialogue: Sam, if she's here...

Speaker: sam
Dialogue: She isn't!

Speaker: arbogast
Dialogue: You came up here on a hunch, Miss Crane? Nothing more? No phone call... from him, or from your sister herself?

Speaker: lila
Dialogue: Not even a hunch. Just hope.

Speaker: arbogast
Dialogue: With a little checking, I could get to believe you.

Speaker: lila
Dialogue: I don't care if you do or... I want to see Mary... before she gets in any deeper...

Speaker: sam
Dialogue: Did you check in Phoenix... hospitals... maybe she had an accident... a hold-up...

Speaker: arbogast
Dialogue: She was seen leaving town in her car. Seen by her very victims, I might add.

Speaker: sam
Dialogue: Do you?

Speaker: lila
Dialogue: Yes... I just... did. The moment they told me...

Speaker: sam
Dialogue: You might have doubted for say five minutes or so, Sister.

Speaker: arbogast
Dialogue: We're always quickest to doubt people who have a record for being honest. I think she's here, Miss Crane. Where there's a boyfriend...  She won't be back there among the nuts and bolts... but she'll be in this town... somewhere. I'll find her.

Speaker: lila
Dialogue: I just listened... and believed everything they told me. 'She stole the money.' 'We don't want to get her in trouble.' 'No don't bring the police in'...

Speaker: sam
Dialogue: It was her boss' idea not to report it to the police?

Speaker: lila
Dialogue: No. The man whose money she... he talked so loud and fast, and I... I should've called the police.

Speaker: sam
Dialogue: He must have had a darn good reason for wanting them kept out of it... All that cash...

Speaker: lila
Dialogue: I ought to call the police right now!

Speaker: sam
Dialogue: No.

Speaker: lila
Dialogue: Why not? Sam, is she hiding here? Are you two planning to go away with the money?

Speaker: sam
Dialogue: How could I go away? I'm in debt up to my...  If she did steal that money...  It's hard to believe she did because it's hard to see why she would. Unless she had some wild idea that it would help me... us...

Speaker: lila
Dialogue: She haven't even called you?

Speaker: sam
Dialogue: I didn't see her... and I didn't hear from her! Believe that!

Speaker: lila
Dialogue: I need to... I need to believe something. This is the first time I've ever come up against anything I couldn't... understand.

Speaker: sam
Dialogue: You've led a charmed life.

Speaker: lila
Dialogue: No. I just think... anything can be explained. But Mary, doing a thing like this... I don't know how to handle...

Speaker: sam
Dialogue: Maybe we can handle it together.

Speaker: lila
Dialogue: I came flying up here expecting to get some explanation... for all I know, she may be trying to get in touch with me, at home. I'd better go home.

Speaker: sam
Dialogue: I think she'll contact me if she contacts anybody. Why don't you stay here. When she shows up... or calls... be here.

Speaker: lila
Dialogue: You want me to stay here?

Speaker: sam
Dialogue: She'll need both of us.

Speaker: lila
Dialogue: Where... can I stay?

Speaker: sam
Dialogue: After we check you in we'll go to the drugstore and get you a sandwich. Then we'll come back here... and wait.

Speaker: norman
Dialogue: Twelve in fact. Twelve cabins, twelve vacancies.

Speaker: arbogast
Dialogue: In the past two days I've been to so many motels, my eyes are bleary with neon. This is the first one that looked like it was hiding from the world at large.

Speaker: norman
Dialogue: I don't really forget the sign, it just doesn't seem... any use.  Want to register, please?

Speaker: arbogast
Dialogue: Sit down. I don't want to trouble you, just want to ask...

Speaker: norman
Dialogue: No trouble. Today's linen day. I change all the beds once a week, whether they've been used or not... dampness. I hate the smell of dampness.  It's such a dank smell.

Speaker: norman
Dialogue: You out to buy a motel?

Speaker: arbogast
Dialogue: No.

Speaker: norman
Dialogue: Oh. I thought... you said you'd been to so many in two days...  What was it you wanted to ask?

Speaker: arbogast
Dialogue: I'm looking for a missing person.  She isn't in trouble.

Speaker: norman
Dialogue: I didn't think the police went searching for people who weren't in trouble.

Speaker: arbogast
Dialogue: I'm not the police.

Speaker: norman
Dialogue: Oh.

Speaker: arbogast
Dialogue: We have reason to believe she came this way... might have stopped in this area...  Did she stop here?

Speaker: norman
Dialogue: No. No one has stopped here in weeks...

Speaker: arbogast
Dialogue: Mind looking at the picture before committing yourself?

Speaker: norman
Dialogue: Committing myself to what? You sure talk like a Policeman.

Speaker: arbogast
Dialogue: Look at the picture. Please.

Speaker: norman
Dialogue: No. At least I don't recall.

Speaker: arbogast
Dialogue: She might have used an alias. Mary Crane's the real name, but she might've registered...

Speaker: norman
Dialogue: I shouldn't even bother to change the linen. I guess habits die hard. Which reminds me...

Speaker: norman
Dialogue: The vacancy sign. Just in case.

Speaker: arbogast
Dialogue: Now there's a couple even remarking about your sign, and see how easily you forgot them?

Speaker: norman
Dialogue: What?

Speaker: arbogast
Dialogue: You thought no one has stopped here in weeks. Now, try to remember if this girl...

Speaker: arbogast
Dialogue: Maybe she even signed the register... because habits die hard. Let's check it, huh?

Speaker: arbogast
Dialogue: Yes sir! Marie Samuels.  Interesting alias.

Speaker: arbogast
Dialogue: Don't know where she got "Marie," but "Samuels" figures. Her boy friend's name is Sam.  Was she in disguise? Or do you want to check the picture again?

Speaker: norman
Dialogue: I didn't lie to you. I just have trouble keeping track of... time.

Speaker: norman
Dialogue: It was raining and her hair didn't look like that... damped out, I guess.

Speaker: arbogast
Dialogue: Tell me all about her.

Speaker: norman
Dialogue: She arrived kind of late, wet and hungry and she was very tired and went right to bed and left early.

Speaker: arbogast
Dialogue: How early?

Speaker: norman
Dialogue: Very early. Dawn.

Speaker: arbogast
Dialogue: Of which morning?

Speaker: norman
Dialogue: The following morning. Sunday.

Speaker: arbogast
Dialogue: No one met her?

Speaker: norman
Dialogue: No.

Speaker: arbogast
Dialogue: Or arrived with her.

Speaker: norman
Dialogue: No.

Speaker: arbogast
Dialogue: She didn't call anyone? Even locally?

Speaker: norman
Dialogue: No.

Speaker: arbogast
Dialogue: You didn't spend the whole night with her did you?

Speaker: norman
Dialogue: No! Of all...

Speaker: arbogast
Dialogue: How do you know she didn't make a call?

Speaker: norman
Dialogue: She was tired. She said she had a long drive ahead of her, in the morning... Yes, now I'm remembering very clearly because I'm picturing. When you make a picture of the moment in your mind, you can remember every detail. She was sitting back there, no she was standing up, with some sandwich still in her hand, and she said she had to drive a long way.

Speaker: arbogast
Dialogue: Back where?

Speaker: norman
Dialogue: What do you mean?

Speaker: arbogast
Dialogue: You said she was sitting "back there," or standing rather...

Speaker: norman
Dialogue: Oh. My private parlor. She had an awful hunger... so I made her some supper. And then she went to bed and left in the morning. I didn't even see her leave.

Speaker: arbogast
Dialogue: How did she pay you?

Speaker: norman
Dialogue: What?

Speaker: arbogast
Dialogue: Cash or check? For the cabin...

Speaker: norman
Dialogue: Cash.

Speaker: arbogast
Dialogue: And when she left, she never came back.

Speaker: norman
Dialogue: Why should she? I'm sorry, I have work to do, Mr... if you don't mind...

Speaker: arbogast
Dialogue: I do mind. If it don't jell, it ain't aspic!  This ain't jelling.

Speaker: norman
Dialogue: I don't know what you expect me to know about... people come and go...

Speaker: arbogast
Dialogue: She isn't still here, is she?

Speaker: norman
Dialogue: Not at all!

Speaker: arbogast
Dialogue: Suppose I wanted to search the cabins, all twelve... would I need a warrant?

Speaker: norman
Dialogue: Come on.

Speaker: norman
Dialogue: Change your mind?

Speaker: norman
Dialogue: I guess I've got one of those faces you can't help believing.

Speaker: arbogast
Dialogue: Anyone at home?

Speaker: norman
Dialogue: I live there. Alone.

Speaker: arbogast
Dialogue: Someone is sitting in that window.

Speaker: norman
Dialogue: My mother.

Speaker: norman
Dialogue: She's... ill. Confined to her room. It's practically living alone.

Speaker: arbogast
Dialogue: If this girl Mary Crane were here, you'd have no reason to hide her would you?

Speaker: norman
Dialogue: Of course not.

Speaker: arbogast
Dialogue: If she paid you well?

Speaker: norman
Dialogue: Now, look...!

Speaker: arbogast
Dialogue: Or if she had you say... gallantly protecting her... you wouldn't be fooled... you'd know she was just using you. Wouldn't you?

Speaker: norman
Dialogue: I'm not a fool! And I'm not capable of being fooled! Not even by women!

Speaker: arbogast
Dialogue: I didn't mean that as a slur on your manhood. I'm sorry.

Speaker: norman
Dialogue: She didn't fool my mother.

Speaker: arbogast
Dialogue: Your mother met her?  Can I talk to your mother?

Speaker: norman
Dialogue: No. I told you, she's confined...

Speaker: arbogast
Dialogue: Just for a moment. She might have picked up a hint you'd miss.

Speaker: arbogast
Dialogue: Sick old women are sharp. Come on, I won't disturb...

Speaker: norman
Dialogue: No! Just no!  I have one of those breaking points like any other man, believe it or not, and I'm near it. There's just so much pushing I can take and I think...

Speaker: arbogast
Dialogue: All right!  Might save me a lot of leg-work if I could just talk to your mother.  But I'd need a warrant for that, won't I?

Speaker: arbogast
Dialogue: See you in an hour. Or less.

Speaker: arbogast
Dialogue: Bates!

Speaker: sam
Dialogue: Sometimes Saturday night has a lonely sound. Ever notice, Lila?

Speaker: lila
Dialogue: Sam. He said an hour. Or less.

Speaker: sam
Dialogue: It's been three.

Speaker: lila
Dialogue: Are we just going to go on sitting here?

Speaker: sam
Dialogue: He'll be back. Let's sit still and hang on, okay?

Speaker: lila
Dialogue: You have an awfully nice habit, Sam.

Speaker: sam
Dialogue: Hundreds! Which one is your pet?

Speaker: lila
Dialogue: Whenever I start contemplating the panic button, your back straightens up and your eyes get that God-looks- out-for-everybody look and... I feel better.

Speaker: sam
Dialogue: I feel better when you feel better.

Speaker: lila
Dialogue: Where's the old highway?

Speaker: sam
Dialogue: You want to run out there, bust in on Arbogast and the sick old lady, shake her up and maybe spoil everything Arbogast's been building for the last three hours.

Speaker: lila
Dialogue: Yes.

Speaker: sam
Dialogue: That wouldn't be a wise thing to do.

Speaker: lila
Dialogue: Patience doesn't run in our family. Sam, I'm going out there!

Speaker: sam
Dialogue: Arbogast said...

Speaker: lila
Dialogue: An hour! Or less!

Speaker: lila
Dialogue: Sam! Why call when we can go?

Speaker: sam
Dialogue: And maybe pass Arbogast on the road?  Thanks.

Speaker: sam
Dialogue: Probably on his way back right now.

Speaker: lila
Dialogue: Sam, I'm going.

Speaker: sam
Dialogue: You'll never find it.

Speaker: sam
Dialogue: Stay here.

Speaker: lila
Dialogue: Why can't I go out there with you?

Speaker: sam
Dialogue: One of us has to be here in case Arbogast's on the way.

Speaker: lila
Dialogue: Just wait here?

Speaker: sam
Dialogue: Contemplate your... panic button.

Speaker: sam
Dialogue: Arbogast?

Speaker: sam
Dialogue: He didn't come back here?

Speaker: lila
Dialogue: Sam.

Speaker: sam
Dialogue: No Arbogast. No Bates. And only the old lady at home...  A sick old lady unable to answer the door... or unwilling.

Speaker: lila
Dialogue: Where could he have gone?

Speaker: sam
Dialogue: Maybe he got some definite lead. Maybe he went right on...

Speaker: lila
Dialogue: Without calling me?

Speaker: sam
Dialogue: In a hurry.

Speaker: lila
Dialogue: Sam, he called me when he had nothing definite, nothing but a dissatisfied feeling. Don't you think he'd have called if he had anything...

Speaker: sam
Dialogue: Yes. I think he would have.

Speaker: sam
Dialogue: Let's go see Al Chambers.

Speaker: lila
Dialogue: Who's he?

Speaker: sam
Dialogue: He's the Deputy Sheriff around here.

Speaker: sam
Dialogue: Our Deputy sleeps.

Speaker: lila
Dialogue: Well?

Speaker: sam
Dialogue: Nothing.  Just... all the lights out... must be asleep.

Speaker: lila
Dialogue: Does that mean we can't...

Speaker: sam
Dialogue: No. I'm just procrastinating.  People hate when the doorbell rings in the middle of the night.  Come on.

Speaker: sam
Dialogue: Sorry, Mrs. Chambers. I hate bothering you...

Speaker: sam
Dialogue: We have a problem.

Speaker: lila
Dialogue: No, thank you. It's my problem, too.

Speaker: sam
Dialogue: I don't know where to start...  Except at the beginning.

Speaker: lila
Dialogue: Yes.

Speaker: sam
Dialogue: This is Lila Crane, from Phoenix. She's been here for a few days, looking for her sister. There's a private detective helping... and, well, we got a call tonight, from this detective, saying he'd traced Mary...

Speaker: sam
Dialogue: Yes. He traced her to that motel, out on the old highway...

Speaker: sam
Dialogue: He traced her there and called us to say he was going to question Mrs. Bates...

Speaker: sam
Dialogue: No. An old woman, his mother.  That was early this evening. And we haven't seen or heard from him since. I went out to the motel, just got back. No one was in the office, and...

Speaker: lila
Dialogue: Will you help us? I think something's wrong out there!

Speaker: sheriff
Dialogue: Now. Your sister is missing how long?

Speaker: lila
Dialogue: She left Phoenix a week ago yesterday. And no trace until...

Speaker: sheriff
Dialogue: How'd you and this detective come to trace her to Fairvale?

Speaker: sam
Dialogue: They thought she'd be coming to me.

Speaker: sheriff
Dialogue: Left Phoenix under her own steam?

Speaker: lila
Dialogue: Yes.

Speaker: sheriff
Dialogue: She ain't missing so much as she's run away.

Speaker: sam
Dialogue: Yes.

Speaker: sheriff
Dialogue: From what?

Speaker: lila
Dialogue: She stole some money.

Speaker: sheriff
Dialogue: A lot?

Speaker: lila
Dialogue: Forty thousand dollars.

Speaker: sheriff
Dialogue: And the police haven't been able to...

Speaker: sam
Dialogue: Everyone concerned thought... if they could get her to give back the money... they could avoid involving her with the police.

Speaker: sheriff
Dialogue: Explains the private detective. He traced her to the Bates place.  What'd he exactly say when he called you?

Speaker: lila
Dialogue: Mary had been there, one night, and had left.

Speaker: sheriff
Dialogue: With the forty thousand dollars?

Speaker: lila
Dialogue: He didn't mention the money.  What he said on the phone isn't important, is it?  He was supposed to come back after he spoke to the mother, and he didn't! That's what I want you to do something about!

Speaker: sheriff
Dialogue: Like what?

Speaker: lila
Dialogue: Go out there! Find somebody, ask some questions!  I'm sorry if I seem over-anxious to you. I keep thinking... something's wrong. I have to know what!

Speaker: sheriff
Dialogue: I think something's wrong, too, Miss. But not the same thing. I think your private detective is what's wrong.  I think he got himself a hot lead as to where your sister was going... probably from Norman Bates...  and called you to keep you still while he took off after her and the money.

Speaker: lila
Dialogue: He said he was dissatisfied... and was going back.

Speaker: sheriff
Dialogue: At this hour?

Speaker: sam
Dialogue: He was out when I was there. If he's back he probably isn't even in bed yet.

Speaker: sheriff
Dialogue: He wasn't out when you were there. He just wasn't answering the door in the dead of night... like some people do. This fellow lives like a hermit...

Speaker: sheriff
Dialogue: You must remember that bad business out there. About ten years ago...

Speaker: sam
Dialogue: I've only been here five. Right now it feels like ten, but...

Speaker: lila
Dialogue: All right! Then call! At least, call!

Speaker: sheriff
Dialogue: Well, this one wouldn't be a customer, anyway. A private detective, name of...

Speaker: sheriff
Dialogue: Well, I think you oughta unload that place and open up closer in to the action, a smaller place, you know... but...

Speaker: lila
Dialogue: Please!

Speaker: sheriff
Dialogue: Said to give you his regards.

Speaker: sam
Dialogue: Was that all?

Speaker: sheriff
Dialogue: This detective was out there and Norman told him about the girl and the detective thanked him and went away.

Speaker: lila
Dialogue: And he didn't go back? Didn't see the mother?

Speaker: sheriff
Dialogue: You should've called in the police the second you found your sister has skipped. You go starting private investigations, using people you don't even know...

Speaker: lila
Dialogue: What difference does that...

Speaker: sheriff
Dialogue: Your Detective told you a nakedfaced lie.

Speaker: sheriff
Dialogue: He told you he wasn't coming right back cause he wanted to question Norman Bates' mother, right?

Speaker: lila
Dialogue: Yes.

Speaker: sheriff
Dialogue: Norman Bates' mother has been dead and buried in Greenlawn Cemetery for the last ten years!

Speaker: sheriff
Dialogue: It ain't only local history, Sam, it's the only murder-and-suicide case in Fairvale ledgers! Mrs. Bates poisoned this guy she was... involved with, when she found out he was married, then took a helping of the same stuff herself.  Strychnine. Ugly way to die.

Speaker: sam
Dialogue: You mean that old woman I saw sittin' in the window wasn't Norman Bates' mother?

Speaker: sam
Dialogue: I'd know the difference between Mary and an old woman.

Speaker: sheriff
Dialogue: Now wait a minute, Sam. You sure you saw an old woman?

Speaker: sam
Dialogue: Yes! In the house behind the motel. I pounded and called but she... just ignored me.

Speaker: sheriff
Dialogue: And you want to tell me you saw Norman Bates' mother.

Speaker: lila
Dialogue: It must've been. Arbogast said so, too... and he said the young man wouldn't let him see her because she was ill!

Speaker: sheriff
Dialogue: Well, if the woman up there is Mrs. Bates... who's that woman buried out at Greenlawn Cemetery?

Speaker: mother's voice
Dialogue: I am sorry, boy, but you do manage to look ludicrous when you give me orders!

Speaker: norman's voice
Dialogue: Please, mother...

Speaker: mother's voice
Dialogue: I'm staying right here!  This is my room and no one will drag me out of it... least of all my big bold son!

Speaker: norman's voice
Dialogue: They'll come now, Mother. He came after the girl and now someone will come after him! How long do you think you can go on... Mother, please, just for a few days, just so they won't find you!

Speaker: mother's voice
Dialogue: All right, son, put me down and I'll go. I'll go on my own two feet. I can go on my own two feet, can't I?

Speaker: norman's voice
Dialogue: I'll carry you, mother.

Speaker: sam
Dialogue: We thought, if you didn't mind, we'd go out to the motel with you.

Speaker: sheriff
Dialogue: Went out before service.

Speaker: sam
Dialogue: You didn't find anything.

Speaker: sheriff
Dialogue: Nothing. Here, let's clear the path.

Speaker: lila
Dialogue: Did he say anything about my sister?

Speaker: sheriff
Dialogue: Just what he told your detective.

Speaker: sam
Dialogue: No mother.

Speaker: sheriff
Dialogue: You must've seen an illusion, Sam. Now, I know you're not the seeing- illusion type... But no woman was illusion there and I don't believe in ghosts, so there it is!

Speaker: lila
Dialogue: I still feel...

Speaker: sheriff
Dialogue: Can see you do. Sorry I couldn't make you feel better. You want to come to my office this afternoon and report a missing person... And the theft, is what you want to do!  Sooner you drop this thing in the lap of the law, that's the sooner you'll stand a chance of your sister bein' picked up. How about that?

Speaker: lila
Dialogue: I don't know.

Speaker: sam
Dialogue: Maybe I am the seeing-illusions type.

Speaker: lila
Dialogue: You're not.

Speaker: sam
Dialogue: Want me to drop you at the hotel? Or you want to come over to the store?

Speaker: lila
Dialogue: I won't feel satisfied unless I got out there, Sam.

Speaker: sam
Dialogue: Neither will I.

Speaker: lila
Dialogue: I wonder if we'll ever see Mary again.

Speaker: sam
Dialogue: Of course we will.

Speaker: lila
Dialogue: Alive.

Speaker: lila
Dialogue: We lived together all our lives.

Speaker: sam
Dialogue: Where'd you go to college?

Speaker: lila
Dialogue: I didn't. I got a job, too.  I wonder if that hurt her, my not letting her sacrifice for me?  Some people are so willing to suffer for you that they suffer more if you don't let them.

Speaker: sam
Dialogue: She was willing to lick the stamps.

Speaker: lila
Dialogue: I wonder so many things about her now.  Why she never told me about you...  Funny, when you think there's an answer to everything, you think you know all the answers.

Speaker: sam
Dialogue: We were going to get married. Are going to get married!

Speaker: lila
Dialogue: Do you know how I found out about you? I found one of your letters... it was a nice letter, Sam.

Speaker: sam
Dialogue: This is the old highway.

Speaker: lila
Dialogue: I suppose... when you were able to marry her she'd have presented you, all shiny and proper... she always tried to be proper.

Speaker: sam
Dialogue: Watch your tenses.

Speaker: lila
Dialogue: Huh?

Speaker: sam
Dialogue: She always tries to be proper.

Speaker: lila
Dialogue: You going to wait here for me?

Speaker: sam
Dialogue: I'm going with you. But we'd better decide what we're going to say and do when we walk in...

Speaker: lila
Dialogue: We're going to register. As man and wife. And get shown to a cabin... and then search every inch of that place, inside and... outside.

Speaker: sam
Dialogue: You won't believe it...  But this will be the first time I've ever pulled one of those man- and-wife-renting-cabin capers!

Speaker: lila
Dialogue: I believe it.

Speaker: sam
Dialogue: I wonder where Norman Bates does his hermiting?

Speaker: lila
Dialogue: Someone was at that window. I saw the curtain move.

Speaker: sam
Dialogue: Come on.

Speaker: sam
Dialogue: Just coming up to ring for you.

Speaker: norman
Dialogue: I suppose you want a cabin.

Speaker: sam
Dialogue: We'd hoped to make it straight to San Francisco, but we don't like the look of that sky. Looks like a bad day coming... doesn't it.

Speaker: norman
Dialogue: I'll take you to...

Speaker: sam
Dialogue: Better sign in first, hasn't we?

Speaker: norman
Dialogue: It isn't necessary.

Speaker: sam
Dialogue: Uh, uh! My boss is paying for this trip... ninety percent business... and he wants practically notarized receipts. I better sign in and get a receipt.

Speaker: norman
Dialogue: I'll get your bags.

Speaker: sam
Dialogue: Haven't any.

Speaker: norman
Dialogue: I'll show you the cabin.

Speaker: sam
Dialogue: First time I've seen it happen.  Check in any place in this country without bags, and you have to pay in advance.

Speaker: norman
Dialogue: Ten dollars...

Speaker: sam
Dialogue: That receipt...?

Speaker: lila
Dialogue: I'll start ahead.

Speaker: sam
Dialogue: Don't bother yourself... we'll find it.

Speaker: lila
Dialogue: We should have asked for Cabin One... The one Mary was in.

Speaker: sam
Dialogue: I'm glad we didn't.

Speaker: lila
Dialogue: We have to go into that cabin and search it, Sam... no matter what we're afraid of finding and no matter how much it may hurt.

Speaker: sam

Speaker: simon
Dialogue: When Norman met your sister, he was touched by her... and aroused by her. He wanted her. And this set off his "jealous mother" and...  "mother killed the girl." Speaker: sam
Dialogue: Why was he... dressed like that?

Speaker: district attorney
Dialogue: He's a transvestite!

Dialogue: Not exactly. A man who dresses in woman's clothing in order to achieve a sexual change... or satisfaction... is a transvestite.  But in Norman's case, he was simply doing everything possible to keep alive the illusion of his mother being alive. And whenever reality came too close, when danger or desire threatened that illusion, he'd dress up, even to a cheap wig he brought, and he'd walk about the house, sit in her chair, speak in her voice... He tried to be his mother.  When the mind houses two personalities, there is always a battle. In Norman's case, the battle is over... and the dominant personality has won.
